Literature Review: The visual system's ability to reconstruct three-dimensional (3D) representations from two-dimensional (2D) retinal inputs is a fundamental aspect of perception in primates. This literature review synthesizes current research on neuronal representations supporting 3D vision in nonhuman primates, focusing on the specialized processing channels within the dorsal and ventral visual pathways.The dorsal and ventral pathways, often referred to as the 'where' and 'what' pathways respectively, have been extensively studied in the context of visual processing. Recent research has revealed that both pathways contribute to 3D vision, albeit through distinct mechanisms. In the dorsal pathway, neurons in the middle temporal (MT) area have been found to encode 3D motion information. Nadler et al. (2013) demonstrated that MT neurons are selective for the direction of motion in depth, suggesting a crucial role in processing dynamic 3D environments.The ventral pathway, traditionally associated with object recognition, also plays a significant role in 3D vision. Studies have shown that neurons in the inferior temporal (IT) cortex are sensitive to 3D shape information. For instance, Yamane et al. (2008) found that IT neurons respond selectively to specific 3D object structures, indicating a representation of complex 3D shapes in this region.Stereopsis, the perception of depth from binocular disparity, is a key mechanism in 3D vision. Neurons sensitive to binocular disparity have been identified throughout the visual cortex, but recent research has highlighted the importance of the V3A area in this process. Preston et al. (2008) found that V3A neurons in macaques show strong selectivity for binocular disparity, suggesting a crucial role in stereoscopic depth perception.The processing of 3D orientation information is another critical aspect of 3D vision. Neurons in the caudal intraparietal (CIP) area have been shown to encode the 3D orientation of surfaces. Taira et al. (2000) demonstrated that CIP neurons respond selectively to the tilt and slant of planar surfaces, contributing to the perception of 3D object orientation.While individual areas specialize in processing specific 3D features, the integration of these features into coherent 3D percepts remains an active area of research. Evidence suggests that higher-order areas, such as the anterior intraparietal (AIP) area, may play a role in this integration. Theys et al. (2012) found that AIP neurons combine multiple 3D cues, including stereopsis and perspective, to represent complex 3D shapes.The role of area V3A as a potential branchpoint for multiple 3D processing channels has gained increasing attention. Tsao et al. (2003) observed that V3A in macaques shows strong activation during 3D structure-from-motion tasks, suggesting its involvement in both motion and depth processing. The expansion of V3A in humans, as noted by Tootell et al. (1997), may have implications for the evolution of advanced 3D spatial reasoning skills in our species.Recent research has also explored the neural mechanisms underlying the perception of 3D scene structure. Kornblith et al. (2013) found that neurons in the occipital place area (OPA) of macaques respond selectively to 3D scene layout, indicating a role in processing the spatial structure of environments.Despite these advances, several challenges remain in understanding 3D vision in nonhuman primates. One key issue is the integration of multiple depth cues, such as stereopsis, motion parallax, and perspective. While individual cues have been studied extensively, less is known about how the brain combines these cues to form robust 3D percepts. Future research could benefit from experimental paradigms that systematically manipulate multiple depth cues to elucidate their relative contributions and interactions.Another important direction for future research is the exploration of information transmission across brain areas involved in 3D vision. While much is known about the response properties of neurons in individual areas, less is understood about how 3D information is transformed and communicated between areas. Advanced techniques such as simultaneous multi-area recordings and causal manipulation methods could provide valuable insights into these inter-areal interactions.In conclusion, the study of neuronal representations supporting 3D vision in nonhuman primates has revealed a complex network of specialized processing channels within the dorsal and ventral pathways. While significant progress has been made in understanding the neural basis of 3D vision, many questions remain regarding the integration of multiple depth cues, the role of feedback connections, and the evolution of 3D vision capabilities. Continued research in this field promises to deepen our understanding of how the brain constructs our rich, three-dimensional perceptual experience from 2D retinal inputs.
